set.name: Set
set.tagline: A set is a collection of elements with no additional structure imposed upon them.
examples: The set \(\mathbb{Z}\) consists of all of the integers.
The notation \(\emptyset\) denotes the empty set, which contains no elements.
For any sets \(A\) and \(B\), \(B^A\) is the set of all functions from \(A\) to \(B\).

magma.name: Magma
magma.tagline: A magma is a set with a single binary operation, often denoted \(\ast\), defined on it. The term "magma" will be used interchangeably with "groupoid" in some older texts.
examples: The empty set \(\emptyset\) is trivially a magma under the trivial operation.

For a set \(S\), the free magma \(M(S)\) contains all binary trees with elements of \(S\) at its leaves. In this magma, \(a b\) is the tree with \(a\) on the left-hand side and \(b\) on the right-hand side.

The set \(\{r, p, s\}\) of rock-paper-scissors gestures forms a commutative magma under the operation "defeats", where every element is idempotent and the result of the operation on two elements is the "winner" in a classic game of rock-paper-scissors.

semigroup.name: Semigroup
semigroup.tagline: A semigroup \(S\) consists of a set and a single binary operation, satisfying the following property.
props: Associativity: \(\forall a, b, c \in S: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
examples: The empty set forms a semigroup under a trivial operation.
The set containing a single element trivially forms a semigroup.
The set of positive integers forms a semigroup under addition.
Any set forms a semigroup under the "first" operation \(a b = a\), as well as the "last" operation \(a b = b\).

monoid.name: Monoid
monoid.tagline: A monoid \(M\) consists of a set and a single binary operation, satisfying these properties.
props: Associativity: \(\forall a, b, c \in M: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Identity: \(\exists e \in M: \forall a \in M: e a = a = a e\)
examples: The set \(\{e\}\) forms the trivial monoid, containing only the identity element.
Given an alphabet \(\Sigma\), the set \(\Sigma^*\) of strings over the alphabet forms a monoid under concatenation, with the identity element being the empty string \lambda.
The nonnegative integers \(\mathbb{Z}^+\) form a monoid under both addition and multiplication.

edges.algebra: Monoid + Multiplicative Monoid + Nonzero + Nonzero Cancellativity

group.name: Group
group.tagline: A group \(G\) consists of a set and a single binary operation, satisfying these properties.
props: Associativity: \(\forall a, b, c \in G: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Identity: \(\exists e \in G: \forall a \in G: e a = a = a e\)
Inverse: \(\forall a \in G: \exists b \in G: a b = b a = e\)
examples: For any natural number \(n\), \(Z_n = \{0, 1, \dots n\}\) is the cyclic group of order \(n\), with the operation of addition modulo \(n\).
The real numbers \(\mathbb{R}\) under addition form a group. Likewise, the nonzero reals \(\mathbb{R}^*\) under multiplication form a group.
Given a set of order \(n\), the set of bijective functions on that set forms the permutation group \(S_n\) under the operation of function composition.
The integers \(\mathbb{Z}\) under addition form a group. They do not, however, form a group under multiplication.
Given any group \(G\), the automorphism group \(Aut(G)\) consists of all isomorphisms from \(G\) to itself under the operation of morphism composition.

edges.algebra: Group + Zero Element + Nonzero + Additive Abelian Group

abgroup.name: Abelian Group
abgroup.tagline: An Abelian group \(G\) is a group in which the operation is commutative. Specifically, the following properties hold in an Abelian group.
props: Associativity: \(\forall a, b, c \in G: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Identity: \(\exists e \in G: \forall a \in G: e a = a = a e\)
Inverse: \(\forall a \in G: \exists b \in G: a b = b a = e\)
Commutativity: \(\forall a, b \in G: a b = b a\)
examples: The operations of "addition" and "multiplication" are, often, intuitively commutative. Thus, the groups \(\mathbb{R}\) and \(\mathbb{R}^*\) are both Abelian groups, as well as \(\mathbb{Z}\).
The set of \(n \times m\) matrices \(\mathbb{R}^{n \times m}\) forms an Abelian group under addition for all natural numbers \(n\) and \(m\).
For any set \(S\), the power set \(\mathcal{P}(S)\) forms a Abelian group under symmetric set difference, where the identity is the empty set and the inverse of an element is its complement in \(S\).

edges.algebra: Abelian Group + Multiplicative Monoid + Nonzero + Nonzero Cancellativity
Abelian Group + Nonzero + Multiplicative Abelian Group
Abelian Group + Nonzero + Zero Element + Additive Abelian Group

quasigroup.name: Quasigroup
quasigroup.tagline: A quasigroup \(Q\) is a set equipped with a single binary operation satisfying the following properties.
props: Left Division: \(\forall a, b \in Q: \exists! x \in Q: a \ast x = b\)
Right Division: \(\forall a, b \in Q: \exists! y \in Q: y \ast a = b\)
examples: For any group, the subtraction operation of the group forms a quasigroup.

loop.name: Loop
loop.tagline: A loop \(Q\) is a quasigroup which contains an identity element. More formally, the following must hold in a loop.
props: Left Division: \(\forall a, b \in Q: \exists! x \in Q: a \ast x = b\)
Right Division: \(\forall a, b \in Q: \exists! y \in Q: y \ast a = b\)
Identity: \(\exists e \in Q: \forall a \in Q: e \ast a = a = a \ast e\)
examples: The set of nonzero octonions forms a loop under multiplication; the real number \(1\) is the identity, but octonion multiplication is not associative.

rack.name: Rack
rack.tagline: A rack \(R\) is a set equipped with a single binary operation, often represented as a left-facing triangle \(\triangleleft\), satisfying the following.
props: Left Division: \(\forall a, b \in R: \exists! x \in R: a \triangleleft x = b\)
Left Self-Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: a \triangleleft (b \triangleleft c) = (a \triangleleft b) \triangleleft (a \triangleleft c)\)

quandle.name: Quandle
quandle.tagline: A quandle \(Q\) is an idempotent rack. More specifically, a quandle satisfies the following properties.
props: Left Division: \(\forall a, b \in Q: \exists! x \in Q: a \triangleleft x = b\)
Left Self-Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in Q: a \triangleleft (b \triangleleft c) = (a \triangleleft b) \triangleleft (a \triangleleft c)\)
Idempotence: \(\forall a \in Q: a \triangleleft a = a\)
examples: Every group \(G\) gives rise to a quandle defined by conjugation. That is, \(a \triangleleft b = a b a^{-1}\).

semiring.name: Semiring
semiring.tagline: A semiring \(R\) is a set equipped with two binary operations, referred to as addition and multiplication, where addition is a commutative monoid and multiplication is a semigroup satisfying distributivity. That is, the following properties are satisfied.
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in R: \forall a \in R: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in R: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
examples: The extended natural numbers \(\mathbb{N} \cup \{\infty\}\) form a semiring under standard addition and multiplication, with the assumption that \(0 \cdot \infty = 0\).
The set of even natural numbers \(2 \mathbb{N}\) form a semiring. Note that this set lacks a multiplicative identity.

nearring.name: Near-ring
nearring.tagline: A near-ring \(N\) is a set together with addition and multiplication operations, where addition forms a group and multiplication forms a semigroup satisfying distributivity. That is, the following properties define a near-ring.
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in N: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in N: \forall a \in N: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in N: \exists b \in N: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in N: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in N: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
examples: For any group \(G\), the set of endomorphisms \(End(G)\) forms a near-ring with addition defined pointwise and multiplication defined as morphism composition.

ring.name: Ring
ring.tagline: A ring \(R\) is an Abelian group with a multiplicative semigroup that distributes over it. The following properties are satisfied.
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in R: \forall a \in R: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in R: \exists b \in R: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in R: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
form: Note that some texts require a multiplicative identity in a ring. Those texts generally refer to this structure as a "pseudo-ring". Conversely, some texts remove the constraint that multiplication be associative.
examples: The smallest ring is a ring of one element \(\{0\}\). This is referred to as the zero ring.
The integers \(\mathbb{Z}\) form a ring under standard addition and multiplication.
The even integers \(2 \mathbb{Z}\) form a ring under standard addition and multiplication. This example is notable in that it lacks a unity (multiplicative identity) element.
The set of square matrices \(\mathbb{R}^{n \times n}\) forms a ring under matrix addition and multiplication for any natural number \(n\).

edges.algebra: Ring + Action Space + Left Scalar Multiplication
Ring + Action Space + Right Scalar Multiplication

commring.name: Commutative Ring
commring.tagline: A commutative ring \(R\) is a ring in which the multiplication operation is also commutative. Specifically, the following hold.
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in R: \forall a \in R: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in R: \exists b \in R: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in R: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Commutativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b \in R: a b = b a\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
examples: The zero ring \(\{0\}\) is trivially a commutative ring.
The integers \(\mathbb{Z}\), rationals \(\mathbb{Q}\), and reals \(\mathbb{R}\) all form commutative rings under the natural addition and multiplication operations.

edges.algebra: Commutative Ring + Nonzero + Nonzero Cancellativity + Identity (Multiplicative)

unitalring.name: Unital Ring
unitalring.tagline: A unital ring \(R\) is a ring which has a multiplicative identity, often called the unity element. Note that some texts refer to this structure simply as a ring. A unital ring satisfies the following.
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in R: \forall a \in R: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in R: \exists b \in R: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in R: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Identity (Multiplicative): \(\exists 1 \in R: \forall a \in R: 1 a = a = a 1\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
examples: The integers \(\mathbb{Z}\), rationals \(\mathbb{Q}\), and reals \(\mathbb{R}\) are all unital rings with the unity element equal to the number \(1\).
The ring of square matrices \(\mathbb{R}^{n \times n}\) is unital for any natural number \(n\). The unity element is the identity matrix \(I_n\).

edges.algebra: Unital Ring + Nonzero + Nonzero Cancellativity + Commutativity (Multiplicative)

integraldomain.name: Integral Domain
integraldomain.tagline: An integral domain \(R\)is a nonzero commutative ring with unity in which the product of any two nonzero elements is nonzero. Precisely, the following properties hold.
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in R: \forall a \in R: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in R: \exists b \in R: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in R: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Identity (Multiplicative): \(\exists 1 \in R: \forall a \in R: 1 a = a = a 1\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
Nonzero: \(0 \neq 1\)
Nonzero Cancellativity: \(\forall b, c \in R: \forall a \in R - \{0\}: a b = a c \Rightarrow b = c\)
examples: The integers \(\mathbb{Z}\) under the natural operations are the typical example of an integral domain.
The ring \(Z_p\) of nonnegative integers less than \(p\) forms an integral domain if and only if \(p\) is prime.
The polynomial ring \(\mathbb{R}[x]\) forms an integral domain.

edges.algebra: Integral Domain - Nonzero - Nonzero Cancellativity - Identity (Multiplicative)
Integral Domain - Nonzero - Nonzero Cancellativity - Commutativity (Multiplicative)

divisionring.name: Division Ring
divisionring.tagline: A division ring \(R\) is a nonzero, unital ring in which every nonzero element has a multiplicative inverse. Division rings are also called skew fields. They satisfy the following properties.
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in R: \forall a \in R: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in R: \exists b \in R: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in R: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Identity (Multiplicative): \(\exists 1 \in R: \forall a \in R: 1 a = a = a 1\)
Inverse (Multiplicative): \(\forall a \in R: a \neq 0 \Rightarrow \exists b \in R: a b = b a = 1\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
Nonzero: \(0 \neq 1\)
examples: The quaternions \(\mathbb{H}\) form a division ring which is not a field.

field.name: Field
field.tagline: A field \(F\) is a nonzero ring whose nonzero elements form an Abelian group under multiplication. They satisfy the following properties.
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in F: \forall a \in F: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in F: \exists b \in F: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in F: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Identity (Multiplicative): \(\exists 1 \in F: \forall a \in F: 1 a = a = a 1\)
Inverse (Multiplicative): \(\forall a \in F: a \neq 0 \Rightarrow \exists b \in F: a b = b a = 1\)
Commutativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b \in F: a b = b a\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in F: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
Nonzero: \(0 \neq 1\)
examples: The ring \(Z_p\) of nonnegative integers less than \(p\) form a field if and only if \(p\) is prime.
The real numbers \(\mathbb{R}\) and the rational numbers \(\mathbb{Q}\) form fields under the natural operations.

edges.algebra: Field + Action Space + Vector Multiplication + Associativity (Vector Multiplicative)

expfield.name: Exponential Field
expfield.tagline: An exponential field \(F\) is a field with an additional function \(E : F ightarrow F\) that is called the exponential function and is required to be a homomorphism from the additive group of \(F\) to the multiplicative group of \(F\). The exponential field as a whole satisfies the following properties.
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in F: \forall a \in F: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in F: \exists b \in F: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in F: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Identity (Multiplicative): \(\exists 1 \in F: \forall a \in F: 1 a = a = a 1\)
Inverse (Multiplicative): \(\forall a \in F: a \neq 0 \Rightarrow \exists b \in F: a b = b a = 1\)
Commutativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b \in F: a b = b a\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in F: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
Nonzero: \(0 \neq 1\)
Exponential Preservation: \(\forall a, b \in F: E(a + b) = E(a) E(b)\)
Exponential Identity: \(E(0) = 1\)
examples: Every field gives rise to a trivial exponential field defined by \(E(x) = 1\).
The field of real numbers \(\mathbb{R}\) forms infinitely many distinct exponential fields. For any positive real number \(a\), a corresponding exponential function can be defined \(E(x) = a^x\).

proset.name: Proset
proset.tagline: A proset \(P\) is a set equipped with a relation, usually denoted \(\le\), which is transitive and reflexive. The relation is called a preorder or quasiorder. The following properties are met.
props: Reflexivity: \(\forall a \in P: a \le a\)
Transitivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in P: a \le b \wedge b \le c \Rightarrow a \le b\)
examples: Given a directed graph, the "reachability" relation defined so that \(a \le b\) if and only if there exists an \(a b\)-path is a proset.

poset.name: Poset
poset.tagline: A poset is a set \(P\) equipped with a relation \(\le\) which is reflexive, antisymmetric, and transitive. The relation is called a partial order. More precisely, the following are satisfied.
props: Reflexivity: \(\forall a \in P: a \le a\)
Antisymmetry: \(\forall a, b \in P: a \le b \wedge b \le a \Rightarrow a = b\)
Transitivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in P: a \le b \wedge b \le c \Rightarrow a \le b\)
examples: For any set \(S\), the power set \(\mathcal{P}(S)\) forms a partial ordering on the relation of subset \(\subseteq\).
The integers \(\mathbb{Z}\) form a partial ordering under the relation of divisibility \(a \le b \Leftrightarrow a | b

setoid.name: Setoid
setoid.tagline: A setoid \(S\) is a set equipped with an equivalence relation \(\sim\) which is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive. Formally, the following properties are satisfied.
props: Reflexivity: \(\forall a \in S: a \sim a\)
Symmetry: \(\forall a, b \in S: a \sim b \Rightarrow b \sim a\)
Transitivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in S: a \sim b \wedge b \sim c \Rightarrow a \sim b\)
form: A setoid can also be defined in terms of its partitions, or equivalence classes. An equivalence relation \(S\) defined in this way is defined as a set of nonempty subsets \(S_i\) of the underlying set, with the property that the intersection of any two such distinct subsets is the empty set and that the union of all the \(S_i\) subsets is the original set.
examples: Equality forms an equivalence relation that makes every set a setoid. That is, \(a \sim b \Leftrightarrow a = b\).
Another trivial equivalence relation comes about by relating every element to every other element so that \(a \sim b\) is true for all \(a\) and \(b\).
Parity on the integers forms an equivalence relation, defined as \(a \sim b\) iff \(a\) and \(b\) are either both even or both odd.

chain.name: Chain
chain.tagline: A chain \(X\) is a set equipped with a total order. The following properties are satisfied by a chain.
props: Reflexivity: \(\forall a \in X: a \le a\)
Antisymmetry: \(\forall a, b \in X: a \le b \wedge b \le a \Rightarrow a = b\)
Transitivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in X: a \le b \wedge b \le c \Rightarrow a \le b\)
Totality: \(\forall a, b \in X: a \le b \vee b \le a\)
examples: The standard ordering on the integers \(\mathbb{Z}\) is a total ordering. Likewise, the rationals \(\mathbb{Q}\) and the reals \(\mathbb{R}\) form a chain under the natural ordering.
Given an ordered alphabet \(\Sigma\), the set \(\Sigma^*\) of strings over the alphabet is totally ordered under the lexicographical ordering, also called dictionary ordering.

wellorder.name: Well-Ordered Set
wellorder.tagline: A well-ordered set \(S\) is a totally ordered set in which every subset has a least element. Formally speaking, the following holds.
props: Reflexivity: \(\forall a \in S: a \le a\)
Antisymmetry: \(\forall a, b \in S: a \le b \wedge b \le a \Rightarrow a = b\)
Transitivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in S: a \le b \wedge b \le c \Rightarrow a \le b\)
Totality: \(\forall a, b \in S: a \le b \vee b \le a\)
Well-Ordering Property: \(\forall X \in P(S): \exists l \in X: \forall x \in X: l \le x\)
examples: Any set of ordinal numbers is well-ordered. As well, every individual ordinal number is well-ordered. Every well-ordered set is order isomorphic to exactly one ordinal number.
The set of natural numbers \(\mathbb{N}\) is well-ordered under the natural ordering.

relation.name: Relation
relation.tagline: A relation \(R\) on a set \(S\) is a subset of \(S \times S\).
examples: The empty relation on any set relates no elements.

directedgraph.name: Directed Graph
directedgraph.tagline: A directed graph \(G\) is a set of vertices and an irreflexive binary relation, often referred to as the edge set.
props: Irreflexivity: \(\forall a \in G: a \nsim a\)
examples: Any set trivially forms a directed graph with no edges.

graph.name: Graph
graph.tagline: A graph \(G\) is a set of vertices and a binary relation, often referred to as the edge set and denoted \(\sim\), in which the relation is symmetric and irreflexive. Formally, the following properties hold.
props: Irreflexivity: \(\forall a \in G: a \nsim a\)
Symmetry: \(\forall a, b \in G: a \sim b \Rightarrow b \sim a\)
examples: The complete graph \(K_n\) is the graph with \(n\) vertices where every vertex is adjacent to every other vertex.

partialsetoid.name: Partial Setoid
partialsetoid.tagline: A partial setoid \(X\) is a set equipped with a partial equivalence relation \(\sim\), meaning it satisfies transitivity and symmetry. Specifically, the following hold.
props: Symmetry: \(\forall a, b \in S: a \sim b \Rightarrow b \sim a\)
Transitivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in S: a \sim b \wedge b \sim c \Rightarrow a \sim b\)
examples: Any setoid \(S\) can be made a non-setoid which is a partial setoid by introducing a "bottom" element \(\perp\) which is not equal to itself or any other element in the setoid.

orderedfield.name: Ordered Field
orderedfield.tagline: An ordered field \(F\) is a field equipped with a total ordering \(\le\) that is well behaved with respect to the operations of the field. That is, the following hold.
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in F: \forall a \in F: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in F: \exists b \in F: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in F: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Identity (Multiplicative): \(\exists 1 \in F: \forall a \in F: 1 a = a = a 1\)
Inverse (Multiplicative): \(\forall a \in F: a \neq 0 \Rightarrow \exists b \in F: a b = b a = 1\)
Commutativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b \in F: a b = b a\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in F: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
Nonzero: \(0 \neq 1\)
Reflexivity: \(\forall a \in F: a \le a\)
Antisymmetry: \(\forall a, b \in F: a \le b \wedge b \le a \Rightarrow a = b\)
Transitivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in F: a \le b \wedge b \le c \Rightarrow a \le b\)
Totality: \(\forall a, b \in X: a \le b \vee b \le a\)
Order Preservation: \(\forall a, b, c \in F: a \le b \Rightarrow a + c \le b + c\)
Order Positivity: \(\forall a, b \in F: 0 \le a \wedge 0 \le b \Rightarrow 0 \le a b\)
examples: The rational numbers \(\mathbb{Q}\) are the typical example of an ordered field, under the natural operations and relation.
The real numbers \(\mathbb{R}\) form an ordered field under its natural operations and natural ordering as well.

booleanring.name: Boolean Ring
booleanring.tagline: A Boolean ring \(R\) is a ring in which every element is idempotent. Specifically, the following hold.
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in R: \forall a \in R: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in R: \exists b \in R: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in R: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Idempotence (Multiplicative): \(\forall a \in R: a^2 = a\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
examples: The power set \(\mathcal{P}(S)\) of any set \(S\) is a Boolean ring, with addition defined as the symmetric set difference and multiplication defined to be set intersection.

connectedgraph.name: Connected Graph
connectedgraph.tagline: A connected graph \(G\)is an undirected graph in which there is a path between any two distinct vertices. Specifically, a connected graph meets the following requirements.
props: Irreflexivity: \(\forall a \in G: a \nsim a\)
Symmetry: \(\forall a, b \in G: a \sim b \Rightarrow b \sim a\)
Connectivity: \(\forall X \in P(G): (\exists x \in X) \wedge (\exists y \in G - X) \Rightarrow \exists x \in X: \exists y \in G - X: x \sim y\)
examples: The complete graph \(K_n\) is trivially a connected graph for any \(n\).

forest.name: Forest
forest.tagline: A forest \(T\) is an undirected graph which contains no cycles. More precisely, the following hold.
props: Irreflexivity: \(\forall a \in T: a \nsim a\)
Symmetry: \(\forall a, b \in T: a \sim b \Rightarrow b \sim a\)
Acyclic Property: \(\forall x, y \in T: \exists! p \in paths(T): x = p_0 \wedge y = p_n\)
examples: The trivial graph with no edges and any number of vertices is a forest.

tree.name: Tree
tree.tagline: A tree \(T\) is an undirected graph which is connected and acyclic. That is, the following properties hold.
props: Irreflexivity: \(\forall a \in T: a \nsim a\)
Symmetry: \(\forall a, b \in T: a \sim b \Rightarrow b \sim a\)
Connectivity: \(\forall X \in P(T): (\exists x \in X) \wedge (\exists y \in T - X) \Rightarrow \exists x \in X: \exists y \in T - X: x \sim y\)
Acyclic Property: \(\forall x, y \in T: \exists! p \in paths(T): x = p_0 \wedge y = p_n\)
examples: A maze with no cycles forms a tree.

omegagroup.name: Ω-group
omegagroup.tagline: An Ω-group \(G\) is a group with an set \(\Omega\), called the operator domain, and a function from \(G \times \Omega\) to \(G\) denoted using exponential notation \(g^\omega\). The structure must satisfy the following properties.
props: Associativity: \(\forall a, b, c \in G: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Identity: \(\exists e \in G: \forall a \in G: e a = a = a e\)
Inverse: \(\forall a \in G: \exists b \in G: a b = b a = e\)
Distributivity: \(\forall a, b \in G: \forall \omega \in \Omega: (a b)^\omega = a^\omega b^\omega\)
examples: Trivially, any group \(G\) gives rise to an Ω-group with an empty operator domain.

groupaction.name: Group Action
groupaction.tagline: A group action \(G\) is a group together with a set \(X\) and an acting function \(\phi : G \times X \rightarrow X\). The acting function is often denoted with a simple dot \(\phi(g, x) = g . x\). The group action satisfies the following coherence conditions.
props: Associativity: \(\forall a, b, c \in G: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Identity: \(\exists e \in G: \forall a \in G: e a = a = a e\)
Inverse: \(\forall a \in G: \exists b \in G: a b = b a = e\)
Identity Preservation: \(\forall x \in X: e . x = x\)
Compatibility: \(\forall g, h \in G: \forall x \in X: (g h) . x = g . (h . x)\)
examples: There exists a trivial action on any group defined by \(g . x = x\).
Group conjugation is a group action onto the group itself. That is, \(g . x = g^{-1} x g\).

leftmodule.name: Left Module
leftmodule.tagline: A left \(R\)-module \(M\), for a ring \(R\), is an Abelian group which defines a scalar multiplication \(\phi : R \times M \rightarrow M\) (denoted here using a dot to differentiate from ring multiplication) satisfying the following conditions.
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in R: \forall a \in R: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in R: \exists b \in R: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in R: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
Associativity (Vector): \(\forall a, b, c \in A: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Vector): \(\exists 0 \in A: \forall a \in A: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Vector): \(\forall a \in A: \exists b \in A: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Vector): \(\forall a, b \in A: a + b = b + a\)
Compatibility: \(\forall a, b \in R: \forall x \in M: (a b) . x = a . (b . x)\)
Left Vector Distributivity: \(\forall a \in R: \forall x, y \in X: a . (x + y) = a . x + a . y\)
Right Vector Distributivity: \(\forall a, b \in R: \forall x \in X: (a + b) . x = a . x + b . x\)
examples: Every ring \(R\) results in the \(R\)-module of \(R^n\) for every natural number \(n\), formed by pointwise addition and scalar multiplication.

rightmodule.name: Right Module
rightmodule.tagline: A right \(R\)-module \(M\), for a ring \(R\), is an Abelian group which defines a scalar multiplication \(\phi : M \times R \rightarrow M\) (denoted here using a dot to differentiate from ring multiplication) satisfying the following conditions.
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in R: \forall a \in R: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in R: \exists b \in R: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in R: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Associativity (Vector): \(\forall a, b, c \in A: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Vector): \(\exists 0 \in A: \forall a \in A: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Vector): \(\forall a \in A: \exists b \in A: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Vector): \(\forall a, b \in A: a + b = b + a\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
Compatibility: \(\forall a, b \in R: \forall x \in M: x . (a b) = (x . a) . b\)
Left Vector Distributivity: \(\forall a, b \in R: \forall x \in X: x . (a + b) = x . a + x . b\)
Right Vector Distributivity: \(\forall a \in R: \forall x, y \in X: (x + y) . a = x . a + y . a\)
examples: Every ring \(R\) results in the \(R\)-module of \(R^n\) for every natural number \(n\), formed by pointwise addition and scalar multiplication.

bimodule.name: Bimodule
bimodule.tagline: An \(R\)-\(S\)-bimodule for rings \(R\) and \(S\) is a left \(R\)-module and a right \(S\)-module in which the multiplication operations are compatible. Specifically, the following hold.
props: Associativity (Additive, Left): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive, Left): \(\exists 0 \in R: \forall a \in R: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive, Left): \(\forall a \in R: \exists b \in R: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive, Left): \(\forall a, b \in R: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative, Left): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Left Distributivity (Left): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity (Left): \(\forall a, b, c \in R: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
Compatibility (Left): \(\forall a, b \in R: \forall x \in M: (a b) . x = a . (b . x)\)
Left Vector Distributivity (Left): \(\forall a \in R: \forall x, y \in X: a . (x + y) = a . x + a . y\)
Right Vector Distributivity (Left): \(\forall a, b \in R: \forall x \in X: (a + b) . x = a . x + b . x\)
Associativity (Additive, Right): \(\forall a, b, c \in S: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive, Right): \(\exists 0 \in S: \forall a \in S: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive, Right): \(\forall a \in S: \exists b \in S: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive, Right): \(\forall a, b \in S: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative, Right): \(\forall a, b, c \in S: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Left Distributivity (Right): \(\forall a, b, c \in S: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity (Right): \(\forall a, b, c \in S: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
Compatibility (Right): \(\forall a, b \in S: \forall x \in M: x . (a b) = (x . a) . b\)
Left Vector Distributivity (Right): \(\forall a, b \in S: \forall x \in X: x . (a + b) = x . a + x . b\)
Right Vector Distributivity (Right): \(\forall a \in S: \forall x, y \in X: (x + y) . a = x . a + y . a\)
Associativity (Vector): \(\forall a, b, c \in A: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Vector): \(\exists 0 \in A: \forall a \in A: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Vector): \(\forall a \in A: \exists b \in A: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Vector): \(\forall a, b \in A: a + b = b + a\)
Bimodule Compatibility: \(\forall a \in R: \forall b \in S: \forall x \in M: (r . m) . s = r . (m . s)\)
examples: Every ring \(R\) forms an \(R\)-bimodule over itself, with scalar multiplication defined as ring multiplication.

vectorspace.name: Vector Space
vectorspace.tagline: A vector space \(V\) over a field \(F\) is an Abelian group on which scalar multiplication is defined and is compatible with the field operations. Specifically, the following axioms hold.
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in F: \forall a \in F: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in F: \exists b \in F: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in F: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Identity (Multiplicative): \(\exists 1 \in F: \forall a \in F: 1 a = a = a 1\)
Inverse (Multiplicative): \(\forall a \in F: a \neq 0 \Rightarrow \exists b \in F: a b = b a = 1\)
Commutativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b \in F: a b = b a\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in F: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
Nonzero: \(0 \neq 1\)
Associativity (Vector): \(\forall a, b, c \in A: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Vector): \(\exists 0 \in A: \forall a \in A: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Vector): \(\forall a \in A: \exists b \in A: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Vector): \(\forall a, b \in A: a + b = b + a\)
Compatibility: \(\forall a, b \in F: \forall x \in V: (a b) . x = a . (b . x)\)
Left Vector Distributivity: \(\forall a \in F: \forall x, y \in V: a . (x + y) = a . x + a . y\)
Right Vector Distributivity: \(\forall a, b \in F: \forall x \in V: (a + b) . x = a . x + b . x\)
Scalar Identity: \(\forall v \in V: 1 . v = v\)
examples: The basic example of a vector space over \(F\) is \(F^k\) for some natural number \(k\).

edges.algebra: Vector Space - Commutativity (Multiplicative) - Inverse (Multiplicative) + Separate Scalar Multiplications

algebra.name: Algebra
algebra.tagline: An algebra \(A\) over a field \(F\) is a vector space coupled with a bilinear vector product, denoted here with a middle dot \(\cdot\).
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in F: \forall a \in F: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in F: \exists b \in F: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in F: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Identity (Multiplicative): \(\exists 1 \in F: \forall a \in F: 1 a = a = a 1\)
Inverse (Multiplicative): \(\forall a \in F: a \neq 0 \Rightarrow \exists b \in F: a b = b a = 1\)
Commutativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b \in F: a b = b a\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in F: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
Nonzero: \(0 \neq 1\)
Associativity (Vector): \(\forall a, b, c \in A: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Vector): \(\exists 0 \in A: \forall a \in A: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Vector): \(\forall a \in A: \exists b \in A: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Vector): \(\forall a, b \in A: a + b = b + a\)
Compatibility: \(\forall a, b \in F: \forall x \in A: (a b) . x = a . (b . x)\)
Left Vector Distributivity: \(\forall a \in F: \forall x, y \in A: a . (x + y) = a . x + a . y\)
Right Vector Distributivity: \(\forall a, b \in F: \forall x \in A: (a + b) . x = a . x + b . x\)
Scalar Identity: \(\forall a \in A: 1 . a = a\)
Left Linearity: \(\forall x, y, z \in A: x \cdot (y + z) = x \cdot y + x \cdot z\)
Right Linearity: \(\forall x, y, z \in A: (x + y) \cdot z = x \cdot z + y \cdot z\)
Scalar compatibility: \(\forall x, y \in A: \forall a, b \in F: (a . x) \cdot (b . y) = (a b) . (x \cdot y)\)
examples: The set \(\mathbb{C}\) of complex numbers forms an algebra over \(\mathbb{R}\), with the vector product defined as the complex product.
The vector space \(\mathbb{R}^3\) over \(\mathbb{R}\) forms an algebra under the cross product operation.

assocalgebra.name: Associative Algebra
assocalgebra.tagline: An associative algebra \(A\) over a field \(F\) is a vector space coupled with an associative bilinear product, denoted here with a middle dot \(\cdot\).
props: Associativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Additive): \(\exists 0 \in F: \forall a \in F: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Additive): \(\forall a \in F: \exists b \in F: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Additive): \(\forall a, b \in F: a + b = b + a\)
Associativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Identity (Multiplicative): \(\exists 1 \in F: \forall a \in F: 1 a = a = a 1\)
Inverse (Multiplicative): \(\forall a \in F: a \neq 0 \Rightarrow \exists b \in F: a b = b a = 1\)
Commutativity (Multiplicative): \(\forall a, b \in F: a b = b a\)
Left Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in F: a (b + c) = a b + a c\)
Right Distributivity: \(\forall a, b, c \in F: (a + b) c = a c + b c\)
Nonzero: \(0 \neq 1\)
Associativity (Vector): \(\forall a, b, c \in A: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)\)
Identity (Vector): \(\exists 0 \in A: \forall a \in A: 0 + a = a = a + 0\)
Inverse (Vector): \(\forall a \in A: \exists b \in A: a + b = b + a = 0\)
Commutativity (Vector): \(\forall a, b \in A: a + b = b + a\)
Compatibility: \(\forall a, b \in F: \forall x \in A: (a b) . x = a . (b . x)\)
Left Vector Distributivity: \(\forall a \in F: \forall x, y \in A: a . (x + y) = a . x + a . y\)
Right Vector Distributivity: \(\forall a, b \in F: \forall x \in A: (a + b) . x = a . x + b . x\)
Scalar Identity: \(\forall a \in A: 1 . a = a\)
Left Linearity: \(\forall x, y, z \in A: x \cdot (y + z) = x \cdot y + x \cdot z\)
Right Linearity: \(\forall x, y, z \in A: (x + y) \cdot z = x \cdot z + y \cdot z\)
Scalar compatibility: \(\forall x, y \in A: \forall a, b \in F: (a . x) \cdot (b . y) = (a b) . (x \cdot y)\)
Associativity (Vector Multiplicative): \(\forall x, y, z \in A: (x \cdot y) \cdot z) = x \cdot (y \cdot z)\)
examples: The quaternions \(\mathbb{H}\) over the field of reals \(\mathbb{R}\) form an associative algebra.

semilattice.name: Semilattice
semilattice.tagline: A semilattice \(S\) is a set coupled with a binary operation which is commutative, associative, and idempotent. Note that meet-semilattices (defined here) are usually denoted with the operation \(\bigtriangleup\), while the dual but equivalent concept of a join-semilattice is denoted with \(\bigtriangledown\).
props: Associativity: \(\forall a, b, c \in S: (a \bigtriangleup b) \bigtriangleup c = a \bigtriangleup (b \bigtriangleup c)\)
Commutativity: \(\forall a, b \in S: a \bigtriangleup b = b \bigtriangleup a\)
Idempotence: \(\forall a \in S: a \bigtriangleup a = a\)
form: Intuitively, a meet-semilattice is a partial order in which each pair of elements has a greatest lower bound. Likewise, a join-semilattice is a partial order in which each pair of elements has a least upper bound.
examples: Every total order on a set \(S\) forms two distinct semilattices with the operations of \(\min\) and \(\max\).
Given an alphabet \(\Sigma\), the set \(\Sigma^*\) on the partial order of "is a prefix of".

band.name: Band
band.tagline: A band \(S\) is an idempotent semigroup. Specifically, it satisfies the following properties.
props: Associativity: \(\forall a, b, c \in S: (a b) c = a (b c)\)
Idempotence: \(\forall a \in S: a a = a\)
examples: Every set \(S\) forms a trivial band under the "first" operation. That is, defining \(a b = a\) for all \(a, b \in S\).

lattice.name: Lattice
lattice.tagline: A lattice \(L\) is a meet-semilattice and a join-semilattice over the same underlying set in which the two operations satisfy absorption properties.
props: Associativity (Meet): \(\forall a, b, c \in L: (a \bigtriangleup b) \bigtriangleup c = a \bigtriangleup (b \bigtriangleup c)\)
Commutativity (Meet): \(\forall a, b \in L: a \bigtriangleup b = b \bigtriangleup a\)
Associativity (Join): \(\forall a, b, c \in L: (a \bigtriangledown b) \bigtriangledown c = a \bigtriangledown (b \bigtriangledown c)\)
Commutativity (Join): \(\forall a, b \in L: a \bigtriangledown b = b \bigtriangledown a\)
Absorption (Join-Meet): \(\forall a, b \in L: a \bigtriangledown (a \bigtriangleup b) = a\)
Absorption (Meet-Join): \(\forall a, b \in L: a \bigtriangleup (a \bigtriangledown b) = a\)
form: Equivalently, a lattice can be defined as a partially-ordered set in which every pair of elements has a meet and a join, where the join is the least-upper bound and the meet is the greatest-lower bound.
examples: The set of natural numbers \(\mathbb{N}\) form a lattice under the ordering of divisibility.

family.name: Family
family.tagline: A family \(\mathcal{F}\) is a set of subsets of a ground set \(S\).
examples: The power set \(\mathcal{P}(S)\) is the largest possible family of subsets for a set \(S\).
The empty set \(\emptyset\) is the empty family of sets.

indsystem.name: Independence System
indsystem.tagline: An independence system \(I\) on a ground set \(E\) is a collection of subsets, called independent sets, satisfying certain properties.
props: Nonempty: \(I \neq \emptyset\)
Hereditary Property: \(\forall X \in \mathcal{P}(E): X \in I \Rightarrow \forall Y \subseteq X: Y \in I\)
examples: For any natural number \(n\), the set of all subsets consisting only of elements strictly less than \(n\) forms an independence system.
Over the integers \(\mathbb{Z}\), the set of all subsets whose elements are either all even or all odd forms an independence system

matroid.name: Matroid
matroid.tagline: A matroid \(M\) is a ground set \(E\) with an associated family \(I\) of subsets satisfying certain conditions.
props: Nonempty: \(I \neq \emptyset\)
Hereditary Property: \(\forall X \in \mathcal{P}(E): X \in I \Rightarrow \forall Y \subseteq X: Y \in I\)
Augmentation Property: \(\forall A, B \in I: |A| > |B| \Rightarrow \exists x \in A - B: B \cup \{x\} \in I\)
form: There are several equivalent ways to define a matroid. The above definition is based on the notion of independent sets. A matroid can also be defined in terms of its bases, or maximally independent sets, as well as its circuits, or minimally dependent sets.
examples: Given any vector space \(V\), the set of linearly independent sets of vectors in \(V\) forms a matroid.
Every undirected graph \(G\) gives rise to a matroid with ground set \(E(G)\) whose circuits are all of the circuits in the graph \(G\).
